questions.text: Which of the following  acts as the primary trigger for onset of labour in pregnant women?
questions.solution:
The fetal ACTH causes an increase in estrogen acting as the onset of labour in pregnant women. It results in the growth of the fetal adrenal gland which has the capacity for steroid biosynthesis i.e. estrogen.

Daily steroid production of fetal adrenal glands near term is more than in adults.

questions.text: All of the following changes are seen during cervical ripening in a patient except _____.
questions.solution:
Collagen fibrils are loosely packed during cervical ripening.

Changes in cervical ripening:

  • Collagen fibril diameter is increased, and there is increased spacing between fibrils leading to increased tissue compliance
  • Increase in the amount of proteoglycan and glycosaminoglycan within the matrix
  • Stromal invasion with inflammatory cells

questions.text: An obstetrician performs the following procedure for labor induction in a patient. What is the reflex elicited in the process?
questions.solution:
Stripping of membranes is depicted in the image, which elicits the Ferguson reflex.

Fetal ejection reflex or Ferguson reflex is a phenomenon in which mechanical stretching of the internal cervix enhances uterine activity. Release of oxytocin from the maternal pituitary has been suggested but not proven.

It is seen in stripping/sweeping and artificial rupture of membranes. Both of these are methods of induction of labor. It is associated with an increase in blood levels of prostaglandin F2α metabolite, also known as dinoprost/carboprost.

questions.text: Which of the following image shows the Duncan method?
questions.solution:
Image B shows the Duncan method of placental separation. 
 

Comparison between two types of placental separation methods:

Schultze method Duncan method
Separation begins from the center of the placenta to the periphery. Separation begins from the periphery to the center.
Blood does not escape externally, as the blood pours into the membrane sac. Blood escapes from the vagina as the blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall.

Brandt Andrew's method or controlled cord traction is a manoeuvre of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labour. 

One hand grasps the umbilical cord while the other is placed on the mother's abdomen with the fingers over the anterior surface of the uterus. While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backwards and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord.

Type III placenta previa is a type of incomplete or partial central placenta previa. Here, the placenta covers the internal os partially i.e. it covers the internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated.

questions.text: In which stage of labour, is the following expelled?
questions.solution:
The placenta and membranes are expelled in the third stage of labour.

The clinical stages of labour may be summarized as follows:

Stages of labour Definition
First True labour pain to full dilatation of cervix
Second Full dilatation of cervix to expulsion of fetus
Third Expulsion of fetus to expulsion of placenta
Fourth One hour observation after the expulsion of placenta

questions.text: All of the following are included in the first stage of labour for a pregnant woman except:
questions.solution:
The encirclement of the largest head diameter by the vulval ring is called crowning. This occurs in the second stage of labour.

First stage of labour is divided into 2 phases:

Latent phase Active phase
The onset of true labour pain up to 6cm cervical dilatation From ≥ 6cm cervical dilatation with regular uterine contractions

Duration:

10-12 hours- nullipara

6-8 hours- multipara

Rate of cervical dilatation:

1.2 cm/hr- nullipara

1.5 cm/hr- multipara
Mainly cervical effacement occurs Mainly cervical dilatation occurs

questions.text: What does fetal position refer to?

choices.text: Part of presentation which lies over the internal os
Relation of different parts of fetus to one another
Relation of the denominator to different quadrants of the pelvis
Part of fetus lying in the lower segment of uterus

questions.solution:
Fetal position refers to the bony fixed point of reference on presenting part with respect to different quadrants of the pelvis.

Definition of various terminologies used for fetus in-utero:

Term: Definition:
Lie Relationship of the long axis of fetus to the long axis of the maternal spine
Presentation Part of the fetus occupying the lower pole of the pelvis
Presenting part

Part of the presentation which overlies the internal os
Attitude

The relation of the different parts of the fetus to one another
Denominator

An arbitrary bony fixed point on the presenting part which comes in relation with the various quadrants of the maternal pelvis
Position

Relation of the denominator to the different quadrants of the pelvis
Engagement

When the biparietal diameter has passed the plane of the pelvic brim, the head is said to be engaged.

questions.text: A senior resident examines a primigravida in labour and informs that the fetus is cephalic in attitude of flexion. What is the most common presenting part of this fetus?
questions.solution:
The most common presenting part when the fetus is in attitude of flexion is vertex.

Attitude Presenting part
Complete flexion Vertex (occipitoanterior)
Incomplete flexion Vertex (sinciput)
Deflexion Vertex (occipitoposterior)
Partial extension Brow
Complete extension Face

 

Related Pearl: Fetal Skull Dimensions

Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

questions.text: The ultrasonogram shows the diameter of the fetal head which is taken as a reference for engagement. Which diameter does this refer to?
questions.solution:
The fetal head is said to be engaged when the biparietal diameter (shown in the image) passes through the pelvic brim. Engagement of fetal head is with reference to this biparietal diameter.

It is the greatest transverse diameter in an occiput presentation. It also reflects the gestational age in the second trimester, with a variation of 7-10 days. 

BPD is measured in the transthalamic view, at the level of the thalamus and cavum septum pellucidum (CSP). It is measured from the outer edge of the skull in the near field to the inner edge of the skull in the far field.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of a partograph?
questions.solution:
Fetal temperature is not a part of a partograph.

Assessment of progress of labor is best done by partograph. Components of partograph:

  • Patient identification
  • Fetal heart rate recorded every 30 min
  • Pulse recorded every 30 min
  • Blood pressure and temperature recorded every 4 h
  • Uterine contractions recorded every 30 min
  • Oxytocin-dose and concentration
  • Urine analysis
  • Vaginal examination done every 4 hours
  • State of membranes and colour of liquor

questions.text: What are the cardinal movements of labour?
questions.solution:
The cardinal movements of labour are engagement, descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension, external rotation, expulsion.

(Mnemonic: Every Day FIRE Raises Extremely)

  • Every: Engagement
  • Day: Descent
  • F: Flexion
  • IR: Internal rotation
  • E: Extension
  • Raises: external Rotation
  • Extremely: Expulsion

The most common presentation is cephalic and presenting part is vertex. Head enters the pelvis through transverse diameter majorly and left occipito transverse is the commonest fetal position. Internal rotation of fetal head occurs at the level of ischial spine. In a vertex delivery, the baby's head is delivered by extension and in a breech delivery, the baby's head is delivered by flexion. The best time to give episotomy is after crowning has occured.

questions.text: A multigravida with gestational diabetes mellitus was admitted in labour at term and progressed to full dilatation. The fetal vertex failed to descend beyond -3 station. The descent of the fetus is facilitated by all except:

choices.text: Extension and straightening of the fetal body

questions.solution:
A well-flexed head facilitates internal rotation, not the descent of the presenting part.

The descent of the fetus is brought about by:

  • Pressure of amniotic fluid
  • Direct pressure of the fundus upon the breech with contractions
  • Bearing-down efforts of maternal abdominal muscles
  • Extension and straightening of the fetal body

questions.text: Which of the following is a prerequisite for internal rotation of the fetal head for a woman in labor?
questions.solution:
The tone of levator ani muscles is a prerequisite for internal rotation of the head.

Prerequisites of internal rotation of the head are as follows:

  • Well-flexed head
  • Efficient uterine contraction
  • Favorable shape at mid-pelvic plane
  • Tone of the levator ani muscles

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the internal rotation of the fetal head?

choices.text: Occiput turns towards the transverse axis
Rotation is not essential when the fetus is unusually small
Internal rotation is followed by external rotation
Rotation is earlier in primigravida than in multigravida

questions.solution:
Internal rotation is not essential in the completion of labor when the fetus is unusually small.

Internal rotation begins with the occiput turning away from the transverse axis. In majority, internal rotation is completed by the time the head reaches the pelvic floor. Internal rotation is followed by extension of the head, which is then followed by external rotation.

Rotation occurs earlier in multigravida than primigravida whereas engagement occurs earlier in primigravida than multigravida.

questions.text: What is the minimum rate of cervical dilatation in primigravida during active labour?
questions.solution:
During active labor, the minimal rate of cervical dilatation in primigravida is 1.2 cm/hr.

First stage of labour is divided into 2 phases:

Latent phase Active phase
The onset of true labor pain up to 6 cm cervical dilatation Starts from ≥ 6 cm cervical dilatation with regular uterine contractions

Duration:

12 h (nullipara)
8 h (multipara)

The minimum rate of cervical dilatation:

1.2 cm/h (nullipara)
1.5 cm/h (multipara)
Concerned with cervical effacement Concerned with cervical dilatation

The cervical dilatation ranges from a minimal rate of 1.2 cm - 6.8 cm/hr in nullipara. Also, the multiparas progress faster in the active phase of labor with a minimal dilatation rate of 1.5 cm/hr.

Friedman curve is the sigmoid curve plotting the pattern of cervical dilatation during the latent and active phase of normal labour.

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the WHO guidelines for the management of second stage of labor?

choices.text: Manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of head
Never give warm compress to the perineum

questions.solution:
The practice of guarding the perineum during delivery of the fetal head is part of the WHO management guidelines for the second stage of labor.

The fingers of one hand support the perineum, while the second hand applies pressure to the fetal head to control the speed of crowning. The advantage of this is to prevent perineal tears.

The second stage of labor begins with full dilatation of the cervix and ends with the delivery of the fetus.

The main events include the descent of the fetus (bearing down by the mother, uterine contractions), cardinal movements of labor, and delivery of the fetus.

Second stage  Nulliparous  Multiparous 
Mean/average duration  50 minutes  30 minutes 
Maximum duration  2 hours (+1 with epidural) 1 hour (+1 with epidural)
WHO maximum duration of 2nd stage/diagnosis of arrest  3 hours  2 hours 

Management of the second stage of labor:

  • The most common position used is the dorsal position with the hips flexed, knees flexed and abduction of the thighs. WHO recommends any position of choice including the upright position. 
  • WHO recommendations for the prevention of perineal tears include warm compresses to the perineum, perineal massage, guarding the perineum, and modified Ritgen's maneuver.
  • Modified Ritgen's maneuver: A sterile towel or pad is held in one hand and placed over the perineum; the other hand applies gentle downward pressure on the occiput to promote flexion and controlled delivery of the head (ensuring the smallest diameter of the head passes through the outlet). Once the occiput is born–with gentle pressure, the head is extended–forehead, nose, and mouth are then delivered.
  • WHO doesn't recommend fundal pressure and routine episiotomy.

Other options:

Option A: A liberal or routine episiotomy is discouraged. Episiotomy is indicated in cases of:

  • Shoulder dystocia
  • Breech delivery
  • Fetal macrosomia
  • Operative vaginal deliveries
  • Persistent occiput posterior positions

Option C: Manual techniques, such as massage or application of warm compresses, are recommended for healthy pregnant women requesting pain relief during labor.

Option D: The position that is most comfortable to the mother i.e. upright/squatting position is encouraged. This position gives:

  • less discomfort and difficulty in bearing down
  • less labor pain
  • less perineal/vaginal trauma and wound infections

questions.text: Modified Robson's classification class 1 includes:

choices.text: Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour
Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour

questions.solution:
Class 1 of modified Robson's classification includes nullipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic, spontaneous labor.

It is the most widely accepted classification system available for analyzing characteristics of delivering women worldwide. It consists of 10 patient population categories. The basis for these categories include: 

  • Parity
  • Onset of labor and mode of delivery
  • Gestational age
  • Fetal presentation 
  • No. of fetuses

The modified Robson system classification is as follows:

Class 1 Nullipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic, spontaneous labor
Class 2

Nullipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic

 2a: induced labor  2b: CS before labor
Class 3 Multipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic, spontaneous labor (excludes previous CS)
Class 4 Multipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic   4a: induced labor 4b: CS before labor
Class 5 Multipara, previous CS, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic
Class 6 Nullipara, single, breech
Class 7 Multipara, single, breech (including previous CS)
Class 8 Multiple pregnancies (with or without previous CS)
Class 9 Singleton pregnancy, oblique/transverse lie (with or without previous CS)
Class 10  Single, cephalic <37 weeks (including previous CS)

questions.text: Identify the fetal position in the given image.
questions.solution:
In the given vertex presentation, the fetal position is right occipitoanterior.

Fetal position refers to the relation of the denominator (arbitrary bony fixed point on the presenting part), with respect to different quadrants of the maternal pelvis. In vertex presentation, the denominator is taken as the occiput (which is close to the triangular posterior fontanelle).

To determine the fetal position the following two steps are followed:

  1. Determine the direction in which the occiput is facing:
    • Towards the pubic symphysis - occipito-anterior
    • Towards the sacral promontory - occipito-posterior
    • Midway between pubic symphysis and sacral promontory - occipito-transverse 
  2. Determine if the occiput is facing the left or the right in relation to the materal pelvis

questions.text: Uterine contractions are palpable when its intensity is more than _____.
questions.solution:
Uterine contractions are palpable when the intensity is >10 mmHg.

Uterine contractions cause cervical dilatation at 15 mmHg and are painful beyond 15 mmHg.

Stage of labour      Pressure
1st 40–50 mmHg
2nd 100–120 mmHg
3rd 100–120 mmHg

Units for measuring the intensity of uterine contractions are mmHg and Montevideo units (MV).

1 MV = intensity of uterine contractions x number of contractions in 10 min.

During labour, normal uterine contractions are between 190 and 300 MV and at the time of delivery, it is 300 MV.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 39 weeks of gestation. On examination, you notice the fetal head has appeared at the vulva. Which of the following maneuvers can be used to assist the delivery of the head?
questions.solution:
Ritgen's maneuver is done for delivery of head in normal labor.

This maneuver is done when the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm. A towel is draped and a gloved hand may be used to exert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum. The other hand exerts pressure superiorly against the occiput.

This maneuver allows controlled delivery of the head.

questions.text: Which dermatome is pain in the early stage of labor limited to?
questions.solution:
Pain in the early stage of labor is limited to dermatomes T10-L1. This is of uterine origin.

Pain in the late stage of labour is due to dilatation of cervix and perineal stretching. The nerves carrying the pain include S2,3,4.

questions.text: A young primigravida at 39 weeks of gestation presented to the casualty crying of intense abdominal pain. She was diagnosed to be in labour. Which of the following is not a characteristic of this pain?
questions.solution:
True labor pain is not relieved by enema and sedatives.

It is characterized by the following:

  • Painful uterine contractions at regular intervals
  • The frequency of contractions increases gradually
  • The intensity and duration of contractions increase progressively
  • Associated with 'show'- extrusion of the mucus plug that had previously filled the cervical canal during pregnancy
  • Progressive effacement and dilatation of the cervix
  • Progressive descent of the presenting part
  • Formation of the 'bag of forewaters' i.e., bulging fluid-filled amniotic membrane presenting in front of the fetal head
  • Not relieved by enema or sedatives
Features True labour pains False labour pains
Cervical dilatation and effacement Present Absent
Pain Lower abdomen and back, radiating to thighs Lower abdomen only
Show Present Absent
Bag of water Formed Absent
Relief with enema No Yes

False labour pain is seen more in primigravidae than in parous women. It usually appears prior to the onset of true labor pain by 1 or 2 weeks in primigravidae and by a few days in multiparae.

Such pains are probably due to stretching of the cervix and lower uterine segment with consequent irritation of the neighboring ganglia.

questions.text: You notice the gynecology resident administer the nerve block seen in the image before performing an episiotomy. Which nerve roots are blocked?
questions.solution:
The nerve roots blocked in pudendal nerve block are S2,3,4. It is blocked just above the tip of the ischial spine by piercing the sacrospinous ligament. 

Pudendal nerve block can be used for:

  • Analgesia in the second stage of labor
  • Episiotomy repair
  • Pelvic floor relaxation for outlet instrument delivery
  • Minor procedures of the lower vagina and perineum
  • Perineal analgesia prior to application of vacuum/forceps

Pudendal block does not impact the cervix or upper vagina. It is ineffective for pain relief associated with uterine manipulation such as manual extraction of the placenta.

questions.text: Paracervical block relieves pain from all except:
questions.solution:
Pain from the lower third of the vagina is relieved by pudendal block, not paracervical block.

Paracervical block relieves the pain of uterine contractions and cervical dilatation. It also relieves pain from upper third of the vagina. It is not useful at the time of episiotomy as the lower part of the vagina is not anesthetized.

Note: Paracervical block is no longer considered safe as it causes fetal bradycardia. Epidural analgesia is preferred when complete relief of pain is needed throughout labour.

questions.text: All of the following are indications for early clamping of cord in a new born baby except:
questions.solution:
Postdated pregnancy is not an indication for early cord clamping.

Early cord clamping is indicated in:

  • Birth asphyxia
  • Rh isoimmunization
  • Diabetic mother

The benefits of delayed cord clamping for up to 60 seconds is an increase in total body iron stores, expand blood volume and a decrease in anemia incidence in the neonate.

On the other hand, delayed cord clamping can lead to a higher hemoglobin concentration, which increases risks for hyperbilirubinemia and extended hospitalization for neonatal phototherapy. Delayed cord clamping can also hinder timely neonatal resuscitation.

According to AIIMS Protocols in Neonatology, in uncomplicated preterm birth, delayed cord clamping should be attempted. This is done for a minimum time of 60 seconds after delivery for preterm infants not requiring immediate resuscitation after birth. It states that DCC must be done even if the mother has an HIV infection. But as per the NACO guidelines, early cord clamping is advised.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of placental separation in stage 3 of parturition of a pregnant woman?
questions.solution:
Lengthening of the umbilical cord is seen in placental separation.

Signs of placental separation:

  • The uterus becomes globular, firm, and ballottable (earliest sign to appear)
  • Schroeder's sign - Slight rise of fundal height as the separated placenta comes down in the lower segment and uterus rests over it
  • Slight suprapubic bulging due to separated placenta distending the lower segment.
  • Kustner's sign - On pushing, the uterus cephalad with a hand on the abdomen, the cord no longer recedes
  • A sudden gush of blood
  • Permanent lengthening of cord

Note: Schroeder's ring is a constriction ring/contraction ring formed due to incoordinate uterine action.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the modified WHO partogram?

choices.text: Right side of alert line indicates immediate referral to First Referral Unit (FRU)
Alert and action line are separated by a difference of 4 hours
Each small square in partogram is equal to 1 hour
Partograph recording should be started once the cervical dilatation reaches 4 cm

questions.solution:
Each small square in a modified WHO partogram is equal to 30 minutes. Each small square in a composite WHO partogram is equal to 1 hour.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument commonly used in obstetrics.
questions.solution:
The instrument given in the picture is episiotomy scissors. The angulation in the scissor is to prevent the extension of pelvic tears into the anal margins and obstetric anal sphincter injuries / complete perineal tears.

Complications of episiotomy: 

They can be immediate or remote. 

Immediate complications include an extension of the incision into the rectum, vulval hematoma, wound dehiscence and injury to anal sphincter. 

Remote complications include dyspareunia, chances of perineal lacerations in subsequent labor and scar endometriosis (rare).

Mayo scissors are long and stout scissors. They can be blunt-tipped/pointed tip/straight or curved. Straight mayo scissors are designed for cutting body tissues near the surface of a wound. They are also used to cut sutures and are also known as suture-cutting scissors.

Curved mayo scissors allow much deeper penetration into the wound and are used to cut thick tissues such as those found in the uterus, muscles, breast, and foot. Mayo scissors used for dissection are placed in tissue with the tips closed. The scissors are then opened so that the tips open and spread out the tissue during the dissection process.

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A nursing assistant posted in the obstetric care unit was asked to monitor the progress of labour. After how much dilatation of the cervix, should she start the documentation?
questions.solution:
The WHO Labour Care Guide begins the documentation of labour progression at 5 cm of cervical dilatation.

The WHO Labour Care Guide is a tool designed to help health personnel involved in labour care. It aims to 

  • Guide the monitoring and help in the documentation of the progress of labour.
  • Guide the health professionals to offer supportive care throughout labour.
  • Assist doctors in promptly identifying and addressing emerging labour complications.
  • Prevent the use of unnecessary interventions in labour.
  • Support audits and quality improvement.

The differences between the WHO-modified partograph and the latest WHO Labour Care Guide are tabulated below: 

WHO modified partograph WHO Labour Care Guide
Documentation of labour progression begins at 4 cm of cervical dilatation. Documentation of labour progression begins at 5 cm of cervical dilatation.
Fixed 1 cm/hour ‘alert’ and ‘action’ lines Time-based cut-offs for each centimetre of cervical dilatation to guide the obstetrician to take action. For example, at 5 cm of cervical dilatation, if there is no progress >6 hours, action needs to be taken.
Monitoring of labour is restricted to the first stage only. Monitoring of the second stage of labour is included
No section on supportive care interventions Addition of a section on supportive care of the mother- labour companionship, pain relief, oral fluid intake and posture
Documentation of strength, duration, and frequency of uterine contractions Documentation of only the duration and frequency of uterine contractions

Note: Previously the answer to the question was 4 cm (according to the modified WHO patograph). However, this information is outdated, therefore the answer to this question has been revised per the latest WHO guidelines.
